news uk-news every-covid-rule-being-lted-"UK records  new coronavirus daily deathsByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Boris Johnson has confirmed that all Covid Plan B measures will come to an end in England today, on Thursday January . This means that mandatory mask-wearing on public transport and in shops, work-from-home guidance and the need for Covid passes will all be axed, despite rates of Omicron infection still surging across the country. UK will revert to Plan A with a focus on vaccine rollout, with Health Secretary Sajid Javid warning last Wednesday that itaposs not the end of the road eventhe number of cases are falling.This means that the end of Plan B does not mean the end of restrictions altogether. Here are the rules being removed today and what will remain. What restrictions will be removed when Plan B ends As of Today, Thursday, January , Covid passes for large venues will end. However, Boris Johnson said that venues would have the right to choose on whether or not they want to continue with the policy.Work-from-home guidance ended last week, with people ing to offices almost immediately after it was axed. Similarly, face coverings are no longer a legal requirement in public spaces including transport and shops. Face masks will also no longer be required in classrooms. Though the government no longer mandates wearing masks in any setting, Johnson added urged that people should still think about wearing a mask when in public environments, particularly in crowded or enclosed spaces. Restrictions on visiting care homes will also be eased. But Mr Javid warned that the end of Plan B shouldnapost be seen as the finish line. He urged people to continue taking protective measures including washing hands, ventilating rooms and self-isolatingpositive. Anyone who has yet to receive their Covid vaccines are also being urged to come forward. Which Covid rules will remain   Along with self-isolating for at least five full daysyou get a positive Covid test, the requirement to take lateral flow tests when travelling internationally will remain in place. While legal requirements stay in place for now, Johnson said he hoped to not have to renew self-isolation rules when they expire on March . He added that the aim is to remove the legal requirement for people to isolate after testing positive and replace it with advice and guidance as the virus becomes endemic.  For now, anyone planning to travel abroad need to book and pay for a Covid test before coming back to England - although this will change on February  from amyouaposre double-vaccinated. From now until then the test - either lateral flow or PCR - will have to be taken after you arrive back. If the test comes back positive, you need to self-isolate. Those who arenapost fully vaccinated need to book and pay for day two and day eight tests. You will also have to quarantine at home or the place youaposre staying for  full days. news uk-news everything-know-far-more-contagious-"Omicron: Another more infectious iant will come says doctorByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments UK health officials are officially monitoring a new Covid- strain, nicknamed “stealth Omicron ”, that appears to be more contagious than the original Omicron strain. Early data suggests that BA., a sub-iant believed to have emerged from a mutation of the Omicron coronavirus iant, may be both more transmissible and better able to evade vaccines than the more common BA. sub-lineage.Currently the BA. lineage accounts for % of all cases globally but in Denmark, the BA. has grown rapidly.In the last week of , it accounted for % of all Covid- cases. By the second week of , it accounted for % of cases. On Wednesday, it was reported that BA. had become the dominant strain in Denmark.In a national address on Wednesday, Danish Health Minister Magnus Heunicke said: “There is no evidence that the BA. iant causes more disease, but it must be more contagious.”  Initial calculations by Denmarkaposs top infectious disease authority, Statens Serum Institut, show BA. could be . times more infectious than BA.. So far, early data has not shown a dference in the risk of hospitalisation for BA. compared to BA.. There is some indication that it is more contagious, especially for the unvaccinated, but that it can also infect people who have been vaccinated to a greater extent, SSIaposs technical director Tyra Grove Krause said at the briefing on Wednesday. The BA. has been nicknamed “stealth Omicron” as it is poses a challenge for scientists to track, unlike the original Omicron that stood out on the widely-used PCR tests without the need for extra genome sequencing. The new strain shows up as being S-gene positive under PCR tests, whereas the BA. did not.  According to the World Health Organisation, BA. sequences have been reported in more than  countries, including the UK, Sweden, Norway, Singapore and India. On Friday, the UK Health Security Agency designated BA. a “iant under investigation” – one level below a “iant of concern” – saying it could have a growth advantage. It is the nature of viruses to evolve and mutate, so itaposs to be expected that we will continue to see new iants emerge, Dr Meera Chand, incident director at the UKHSA, said. Our continued genomic surveillance allows us to detect them and assess whether they are signicant.  So far, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether BA. causes more severe illness than omicron BA., but data is limited and UKHSA continues to investigate.” In the UK, some  cases of the BA. sub-lineage have been sequenced, according to Reuters, and the UKHSA said early analysis suggested an increased growth rate compared to BA.. Imperial College London’s Tom Peacock, one of the first virologists to raise the alarm over Omicron, tweeted that very early observations from India and Denmark suggest there is no dramatic dference in severity compared to BA.. This data should become more solidin the coming weeks.”  He added that there is likely to be minimal dferences in vaccine effectiveness against BA. and BA.. Personally, Iaposm not sure BA. is going to have a substantial impact on the current Omicron wave of the pandemic. Several countries are near, or even past the peak of BA. waves. I would be very surprisedBA. caused a second wave at this point. Even with slightly higher transmissibility this absolutely is not a Delta-Omicron change and instead is likely to be slower and more subtle, he continued. title: family told pay over 1600
story: Family told to pay over £, after sons move out in bedroom tax ordealParents Philip Elliot, , and Elizabeth Aslett, , said they feel they are being punished for pushing their sons to do better with their lives by moving out of their three-bed council home to go to uni and collegeParents Philip Elliot, , and Elizabeth Aslett, , were in shock when they received a message saying they owed £,. as their bedroom tax had changed Image: Nottingham Post   BPM MediaByEllie DanemannAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A mum was left in tears as her family is embroiled in a bedroom tax nightmare after they were told to pay more than £, after their two sons moved away.Parents Philip Elliot, , and Elizabeth Aslett, , have been left frustrated at the tax payment and say they will struggle to pay the money.The family have lived in a three-bedroom council house in Bilborough, Nottingham for nearly  years. Their two sons - Ryan Aslett, , and Lewis Aslett,  - left the family home in September of last year to go to university and college, NottinghamshireLive reports. Before they moved out, the parents say they spoke to officials explaining the situation and said their sons would still need their bedrooms for when they come back for the holidays. The couple claim they were initially told this was fine, but then earlier this month they received a message saying they owed £,. as their bedroom tax had changed. Are you enduring a bedroom tax hell  Email webnews@mirror to tell your story They received £, each month from Universal Credit as well as £ from Employment and Support Allowance and Personal Independence Payment [PIP] support.The amount recipients receive towards housing costs may be reduced when a home has spare bedrooms. Bedroom tax means a claimant will receive less in housing benefit or housing cost element in a Universal Credit claim when living in a housing association or council house and deemed to have one or more spare bedrooms. The family were left in utter shock when they were told they needed to pay £,. in the dispute over bedroom tax. Philip said: We told them in August this was going to happen in September, the lady said everything was fine. The money was looking a bit dferent in November so I was a little worried. When I found out it was a shock, nobody had said we owed them money. Weaposve got welfare rights involved and itaposs been sent to the appeal stage. The couple explained they were unable to work due to their disabilities, which means they will struggle to pay the money or be able to survive off the smaller payments. Elizabeth added: I burst into tears and cried, it was so annoying. We donapost know what is round the corner, we had both the boys home for six weeks over Christmas, theyaposre coming back in the next week or so.for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror emailThe DWP apologised for how the familyaposs case had been handled and added that staff were in touch to help them with the appeals process. The family now fear for their future remaining in the house. Philip added: Weaposve got two boys trying to better themselves in le, weaposve put them in the right direction and now we are getting penalised for it. We canapost afford to keep it anymore, we donapost want to move, we donapost have the money to move. We are stuck. A DWP spokesman said: We are very sorry for how Mr Elliott and Ms Assett’s claim has been handled and have been in touch to apologise and to help them with the appeals process. “We have also reviewed their benefits to ensure they are receiving their correct entitlement. The Mirror contacted the DWP for comment. title: former team gb diving coach
story: Exclusive: Former Team GB ing coach struck down by rare condition that makes him appear drunkMarc Holdsworth, , from Leeds, has coached Olympic athletes including Tom Daley, Jack Laugher, and Matty Lee, but for years he has secretly battled a debilitating neurological conditionMarc is fighting to stay on his feet for as long as possible Image: Michelle SharmanByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments A former Team GB Olympic ing coach has revealed the horrying parts of his degenerating neurological condition which makes him appear drunk and recently left him unable to walk unaided. Marc Holdsworth, , has coached Olympic medalists, Tom Daley, Jack Laugher and Matty Lee from pool to podium while secretly facing a devastating battle.Aged , the athlete was diagnosed with Friedrich’s Ataxia - a condition that attacks the nerves which control muscles around the body. This can lead to problems with balance, mobility, vision and speech. After a nasty fall earlier this month, Marc was left unable to walk without a simmer frame. He also requires surgery to repair his anterior cruciate ligament. Brave Marc had never spoken publicly about his diagnosis, but now he has revealed all to The Mirror. He said: “When I speak to the Ataxia nurses and they tell me how well I am doing, I break down. “It’s important for me to stand on my own two feet for as long as I can. “One of the reasons I don’t openly talk about it is that I don’t want to be treated any dferently because I have it. “It would mean the world to be able to keep coaching, I started ing when I was just  so it has been my le. “There’s a lot more moving around than people realise, you have to examine the es from all angles and you’re doing lots of moving between dferent people, I’m not just sitting on a chair at the side of the pool. “Not being able to do what I love is heartbreaking.” Living with Ataxia is like “constantly walking on a balancing beam” Marc says, who also suffers from muscle soreness, fatigue and hypermobility. The latter of those symptoms actually meant he was ‘fine-tuned’ to be a er in his younger years, but he knew something was wrong when he noticed he was unable to do simple things. He said: “I could do somersaults on the floor and arm stands which were great party tricks but I noticed that I couldn’t do simple things like carrying a cup of coffee from one side of the room to another. “I thought that was strange considering the amount of training I had. When I got given the news it was devastating. “The way it was explained was thatI had been diagnosed at  years old I would have been in a wheelchair by the age of . “I was really worried, I was an athlete so was immediately asking questions about what this meant. “They didn’t really have any concrete evidence of what would happen to me. “I have just been trying to keep fighting and enjoying le because it’s degenerative over time. “It’s not at a point where I need a wheelchair but I am on a restricted driving licence which is assessed every year and I have a blue badge.”  Now Marc coaches young ers at the City of Leeds Diving club but has been unable to get to the poolside for months as a result of the injury which is compounded by his condition. In a bid to help him get back on his feet as soon as possible, parents at the club have set up a GoFundMe to raise nearly £, to pay for the operation privately. Overwhelmed by the kindness and support he has had, Marc is determined to raise as much awareness as possible around Ataxia when he is finally able to walk again. Michelle Sharman, whose daughter Jaeda es at the club, is leading the fundraising efforts but admitted that before learning of his condition she thought Marc was always drunk. She said: “I didn’t know about Marc’s condition when I first met him but he always appeared drunk. “The dference in the ers since Marc joined the club is unbelievable. “Jaeda has gone from wanting to quit the sport to finding her love of ing all over again. “When he told me what he was going through it was a no-brainer that we were going to do as much as we could to help.”For more information about Ataxia click here https:www.ataxia.org.uk Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Tom DaleyJack LaugherTeam GBEducationSchoolsSwimmingDiving" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how many times can you
story: How many times can you catch Covid  Most of those with Omicron have been infected beforeA new study has revealed that two-thirds of those infected by Omicron in England have already had Covid. So how many times can you catch coronavirus  Heres everything you need to knowMajority of those infected by Omicron in England have had Covid before Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan |comments Almost three years into the pandemic, most of us have either caught Covid or known someone who has been struck down by it. However, some people have been unlucky enough to catch the virus more than once. Now, an ongoing study fromReact , has found a majority of those who have been infected by the dominant Omicron strain had already been infected by the virus before.The study swab-tested thousands of volunteers in England, and found that two of every threeof the infected volunteers said they had already previously tested positive for Covid. Many of these could have been reinfected, but more work remains to be done to see how many of these are true re-infections. How many times can you catch Covid  You can catch Covid more than once. Some people - including politicians Keir Starmer and Matt Hancock - have had Covid twice, while there have also been other reports of people being infected with the virus three or even four times, sometimes just a few weeks apart.An analysis by the UK Health Security Agencypublished in December revealed that around one in  people who contracted Omicron in England have previously had Covid. Brits will be well aware of the three main symptoms of coronavirus – a new, continuous cough, a fever and a loss of taste and or smell. These are the officially recognised symptoms according to the NHS. However, with the new Omicron iant, symptoms have been described as being more similar to a common cold. Itaposs important to be aware of the symptoms in order to limit the spread of Covid. most common symptoms of Omicron, overtaking the  aposclassicapos Covid symptoms Is a rash a symptom of Omicron  Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron  Warning in your eyes doctor warns could be sign of Omicron Warning signs that the Omicron symptoms youaposre experiencing arenapost mind Omicron symptoms parents may be able to spot in children  least pleasant Omicron symptom – including dizziness  While Covid infection is thought to provide natural immunity, UK studies into Omicron showed that immunity due to infection provides poor protection against the new strain.Another study which took all PCR test-confirmed Covid cases in England from November  and December , found that people who had already contracted coronavirus only had around % protection against Omicron.How soon can you get Covid again  Natural immunity from Covid infection wanes after a period of time. However, it’s not clear how long this initial immune response lasts after the first infection with Covid, and it can y from person to person. According to research, immunity after recovery from Covid can last from three months up to several years. But, some people can get re-infected sooner. A Yale School of Public Health study from October  noted that unvaccinated people should have immunity against reinfection for between three and  months, but this was before the emergence of Omicron. How long does it take to recover from Covid   The amount of time it takes to recover from Covid can be dferent for everybody. While many people feel better in a few days or weeks -making a full recovery within  weeks - others can experience long-Covid symptoms. These long term symptoms can last weeks or months after the infection has gone, and is not linked to how ill you were when you first caught the virus. title: pregnant mum cant stop crying
story: Pregnant mum ‘cant stop crying over council house living conditions nightmareThe young family are all staying in the same room, as the other rooms in the house are ‘not safe’ for the childrenPregnant mum Chloe Pritchard, , says the state of her council home is affecting the health of her young family Image: Chloe PritchardByHarri EvansKatie L Wilson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsA pregnant mum says the horrible living conditions of her council home in Caernarfon are affecting the health and well being of her young family. Chloe Pritchard, , says pieces of wall fall off during the day, water seeps in through several windows whenever it rains, there are cracks everywhere, and her three-year-old son is staying at his grandmotheraposs because it is affecting his health. The young mother also described how there is damp in the house and holes in the wall, which are covered up by wallpaper, NorthWalesLive reports. Chloe moved into the two bedroom house in Caernarfon, Wales with her two young children last November.  The -year-old was happy to find a bigger home for her growing family and was eager to move into the house as soon as possible. She says that the house initially appeared to be an improvement on her previous home, but within days of moving in, she says she realised that a lot of work was required to make it a safe environment for herself and her children.  Three months after moving in, she claims that no progress has been made by the social housing provider Adra in remedying the problems, as she keeps on discovering more issues with the house. Chloe said: Living in this environment is horrible, especially with two children and another one on the way. I canapost stop crying, I canapost eat or sleep here - itaposs no way to live. She said that heat can escape from the house easily, which leaves her having to keep the heating switched on throughout large parts of the day.  These issues are affecting the physical and mental health of her young children, she said. My young son lives mostly with my mum because he canapost stand being in the house. Thereaposs dust everywhere form the crumbling plaster which affects him badly because of his bronchitis. We have damp, some of the plaster is wet to the touch and parts of the walls crumble off at random parts of the day. The sockets are also exposed and thereaposs holes in the walls which are obviously dangerous for young children. The children are stressed out living here. My baby girl whoaposs just turned one wonapost settle and my three-year-old boy absolutely hates coming here. Heaposs always got a cold and his asthma plays up because of how cold, damp and dusty it is here. Heaposs missing school because of it as well. He sees me stressed and heaposs at that age now where that affects him and that just builds up, said Chloe. Chloeaposs baby is due in July and she feels that she is getting nowhere despite being in constant contact with Adra. As things stand, Chloe says, they are all staying in the same room as the others are not safe for her children. I canapost let my baby girl crawl around because the floor is so rough andI was to take my eye off of her for a second she could be sticking a finger into loose plaster or a hole in a wall. Weaposre all staying in one room at the moment because I canapost have my kids in any of the other rooms given the way they are at the moment - itaposs just not safe. Iaposm constantly told by people that these are not living conditions but when I bring the issue up with Adra - something Iaposve done many times - itaposs like theyaposre not interested. Weaposve had inspectors over who acknowledge that work needs to be done on the house but they say we just have to keep on living here and wait months on end for it to be done, Chloe said. Chloe said she feels asshe has exhausted all of her options. She says that she needs Adra to act urgently and that her current situation is not tenable for the long term. Dealing with her pregnancy and all it entails on top of living in this environment, she says, is a nightmare, and she has considered handing back the keys on several occasions.The only thing that is stopping her from doing so, she says, is her responsibility to her children. Iaposve come close on so many occasions to handing my keys back to Adra and just sleep on peopleaposs sofas but obviously with the children involved I canapost do that. I donapost feel like I have any options at the moment.  A spokesperson for Adra said: Providing good customer service and making sure our customers feel safe and comfortable in their home is a priority for us. Our customer moved into this house in November as part of a mutual exchange. In January we were notied about the issues involving some of the plastering in the property. To date we have carried out an inspection at the customeraposs home and have identied the work required which will be completed by the end of February. We will make sure the work is completed to a high standard. It contains  denials as well as  instances in which the team said it lacks sufficient information to admit or deny the allegations. There are also a handful of admissions in the document, in which the Duke demanded a trial by jury. Ms Gufre claims in , she was trafficked by billionaire and convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein and his partner Ghislaine Maxwell to have sex with Prince Andrew in London when she was  - a minor in US law. title: school should scrap hair rules
story: School should scrap hair rules and let kids embrace their heritageAfter a ticking off at her sons school, Eva Simpson knows only too well how out-of-touch guidelines can be. And she applauds the St Albans headteacher who is ripping up the rulebookEva Simpson says schools should scrap their hair rulesImage: Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Jan |comments Like most parents on their child’s first day of ­ secondary school, I was filled with immense pride.My son looked so smart in his new unorm – blazer, tie, shirt, gleaming shoes. I took loads of pictures to show family and friends.When we arrived at the school, a teacher pointed to my son and called out “can this boy’s parent come and see me I stepped forward proudly. I didn’t expect to be singled out for how well turned out and smart my son looked on his first day of big school. “Good morning,” said the teacher. “I’m just wonderingyou read the school’s policy on hair  Your son’s haircut is in contravention of that.” I was stunned. Contravention. What was he on about My son had a perfectly normal hair cut, one that he’d had all through primary school. A short crop, similar to one sported by US President Barack Obama. But as far as the school was concerned it was an “extreme” haircut because it wasn’t a number four or above. In other words it was too short. I won’t lie, I was so upset I was on the verge of tears. Of course in typical British fashion I apologised profusely and assured him it wouldn’t happen again. But I was fuming. It immediately created a ­ision when there didn’t need to be one and left a very bad taste. There have been too many incidents of black children being penalised for hair ­“transgressions”. So I was heartened to read about St Albans headteacher Julie Richardson who has ripped up the school’s rule book on hair and thrown it out of the window.Now kids can come in with cornrows, Afros, short hair, whatever, without being put into isolation and missing valuable teaching time.Too many unorm policies around hair are ridiculous. They ignore children’s cultural heritage. Black schoolgirls for instance have sometimes been banned from having braids as they’re classed as hair extensions, even though they’re neat and mean the child can get ready for school much quicker. This fosters resentment, all to the detriment of the child. Part of the problem is the lack of ­ersity among school governors. It’s a closed shop. Many schools, especially those with a large black student body, have practically no black representation among the governing body and that needs to change. So I applaud Ms Richardson. I hope more schools take a leaf out of her book. story: Supermarket face mask law changes will affect Sainsburys, Lidl and Morrisons shoppersFace masks are no longer mandatory in public spaces across England. But some supermarkets have issued their own advice on the matter - heres what you need to knowThe face mask mandate has been scrapped as Plan B restrictions come to an end in England Image: U. Baumgarten via Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsCovid Plan B restrictions, which were introduced late last year to curb Omicron cases, have been scrapped from today almost in entirety.It means compulsory face masks, Covid passes and work from home guidance have all come to an end in England.Last week, Boris Johnson told the Commons that the government will no longer mandate the wearing of face masks anywhere.He added that instead of mandates, it suggests that you continue to wear a face covering in crowded and enclosed spaces where you may come into contact with other people you do not normally meet.Many supermarket chains have announced their rules on face masks, with one chain saying safety remains our highest priority.Which supermarkets still need you to wear a face mask   Under Plan B, shoppers in England had to wear face masks in shops and supermarkets as well as in a range of other public indoor settings, unless they were exempt or had a reasonable excuse. The end of restrictions means that there is no longer a legal requirement to wear masks in shops.However,supermarket chain Sainsbury’swas among the first retailer to announce it is recommending all shoppers and staff continue to wear a covering unless they are medically exempt.The chain issued an update stating: Safety remains our highest priority. From Thursday, we’re asking our customers and colleagues in England to continue to wear a face covering in our storesthey are able to.Another large chain to confirm that it would be suggesting shoppers to wear masks in their stores wasJohn Lewis .A spokesperson said: We value the safety of our customers and Partners and continue to follow the latest Government guidelines, adding that it will be down to iniduals to make a personal choice. Morrisonsand Waitrose have also confirmed they will be following government guidance but recommending that face masks continue to be used by shoppers in their stores.Wilko said: While masks will no longer be a legal requirement in England, we’re still recommending face coverings for our team members and customers in busy indoor spaces unless they are exempt. Meanwhile, electronics retailer Currys said that while it will ask staff and delivery staff to wear masks, it wonapost tell customers to do the same. Other stores like Tesco and Aldi are likely to follow with a voluntary mask policy, where shoppers will be asked to consider wearing masks but not legally required to do so - but this is unconfirmed as these stores have not issued any update yet.What is the health guidance on using face masks   Face masks are no longer mandated in retail settings and public transport, but health guidance remains that people wear masks in crowded and enclosed spaces, where they may come into contact with people they do not normally meet. Trade union Usdaw, which represents , retail workers, has also urged customers to continue to observe Covid safety measures and wear masks even though the mandate has ended. Chief executive of British Retail Consortium Helen Dickinson said: Retailers ask customers to be considerate to those around them when choosing whether to wear a face covering and to respect the decision of other customers.Similar to shops, Transport For London has already said that people must continue to wear masks on its services. title: teen who faces internal decapitation
story: Exclusive: Teen who faces internal decapitation from rare condition cries as strangers gt £,Allesha Barnfield could become internally decapitated at any time due to a rare condition but after the Mirror helped her tell her story she is crying tears of joy and can fly to Spain for le saving surgeryAllesha is eagerly awaiting surgery in February to save her from this awful condition Image: The MirrorByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A teenager has thanked strangers whose incredible generosity has funded brain surgery to stop a rare condition from internally decapitating her.Allesha Barnfield, , from Highfield, South Yorkshire was diagnosed with Chiari Malformation in September  but is not eligible for surgery on the NHS. The condition means that the ligaments in Allesha’s spine are tense and tighter than usual, subsequently pulling her brain into her spinal canal which causes crippling headaches making sound and light unbearable for the teen.The potentially fatal condition can also lead to ‘internal decapitation’ or paralysis when the tension builds so much that these ligaments become severed. The former law student, whose dreams of becoming a lawyer were initially dashed by the devastating diagnosis, needed £, to fly to Spain and have an innovative new operation which will stop the malformation in her spine. Have you got an incredible story to tell  Email webnews@mirror But following an exclusive Mirror appeal to help her raise the funds she has received an incredible £, from people around the world. Allesha said: “The surgery is booked, all I need to book now is my flights and work out who is going to come with me. “I’m literally so happy it’s unreal, I can’t believe it. “The Mirror is the reason this has all happened, I donapost know where I would be without all these amazing people who have donated and the help I have had to raise awareness.  “Thousands of people have donated, some of them I’ve never met. “I rang my sister crying when we hit £,. I’ve had to take the last few days just to process it. “I never thought I would even manage to raise the money I needed, never mind do it in a few days.” Allesha had started looking for answers three years ago when she was struck down with daily headaches so severe that she can’t bear to look at light or hear anything louder than a whisper. The teenager was forced to give up her placement with a law firm and quit college just as she was about to go to university, instead spending her le confined in a dark quiet room.  Now her surgery at the Filum System clinic in Barcelona is booked for February  and Allesha will be supported by her boyfriend, Kieran, . Although the recovery period ies between patients, Allesha hopes to be home and healthy in time for her th birthday in April, when her le can finally begin again. She said: “Hopefully I will be back up and better in time for my th birthday. “It’s the best birthday present I could ever ask for. “I want to go back and get ready for university and start studying law. “The next step is having the surgery and then taking the time to recover but I want to raise as much awareness as I can about Chiari Malformation. “Even though I’m terried I’m also so excited and feel like I have a new lease of le back. “Before this I just wanted to give up because I thought my le was over. “But now I have a chance to start again.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. Two years into the coronavirus pandemic, normal le is slowly ing in England, with the easing of restrictions and rules. Where youaposre most likely to catch Covid  Displayed in a handy chart, the study has lists the percentage likelihood of becoming infected in dferent situations. If itaposs in a poorly ventilated area, the risk creeps up to .%. title: mum who lost half tongue
story: Mum who lost half her tongue to cancer feels positive with new one made from her legCameron Newsom, , was happy and healthy when she first developed a white spot on her tongue which led to a stage four skin cancer diagnosisCameron Newsom, , first developed a white spot on her tongue Image: Cameron Newsom   SWNSByHarrison MooreKirstie McCrumLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan |commentsA mum who lost half of her tongue to cancer has said she is feeling really positive after getting a new one made from her own leg. Cameron Newsom, , first developed a white spot on her tongue and was referred by her dentist to the local hospital for a biopsy. The spot was not painful and, when the results came back negative for any signs of cancer, she and her husband Anthony, also , and their son Hudson, , were told not to worry.But a year later, Cameron, from Colorado Springs, Colorado, developed another identical spot and was admitted to hospital again for a deeper, more invasive biopsy, Bristol Live reports. The results once again showed no signs of cancer but medical experts couldnapost identy the cause of the spots.  Months later, her tongue became sensitive and sore, and immediately contacted her dentist. She was given antibiotics to combat any potential infection but her condition continued to worsen, as the original spots had transformed into a pinkish tumour on the left side of her tongue. She was sent for further tests and a third biopsy and after being referred to an ear nose and throat specialist, Cameron was diagnosed with stage four squamous cell carcinoma – skin cancer of the tongue. Cameron said: At the time of my diagnosis Iaposd lost over seven pounds because I was unable to eat or drink. It took three years from when the first spot originally appeared for doctors to finally diagnose me - no one ever mentioned it could be oral cancer. When I was told, it seemed like I was being handed a death sentence there and then, but straight away my reaction was Iaposm ready to fight this. I was  at the time and in very good shape, so I couldnapost understand why this was happening to me.  When I got home that day I googled my type of cancer and as you can imagine the results were absolutely terrying. There were images of people after having their jaws removed or sawed in half - Iaposd never been so scared. Cameronaposs diagnosis came in May  and she was scheduled in for three rounds of chemo, starting in July and finishing in September that year. Throughout that time, she was unable to eat or drink anything without suffering excruciating pain - all whilst undergoing grueling cancer treatment. There would be times at the dinner table where I would just burst into tears because I couldnapost eat a thing, she said.results showed no signs of cancer - but medical experts couldnapost identy the cause of the spots. Hudson, who was five at the time, didnapost know why I was always so upset and it got to the point where I couldnapost physically speak to him or my husband. A low point for me was when I went to a party with all my closest friends and I had to leave because my mouth was in so much pain. I went home and took a shower to calm down, and thataposs when clumps of my hair started falling out - it was so upsetting. Thankfully for Cameron, her chemotherapy was successful and as a result the tumor had shrunk a considerable amount. Her body had reacted well to the treatment, but the next part of her recovery was to have the tumor completely removed. She then flew back and forth to the MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas to meet with some of the best oral surgeons in the country and organise the operation. On December , Cameron went under the kne, and oral and plastic surgeons worked together to remove the left side of her tongue. In what was a nine-and-a-half hour operation, they then replaced that part of her tongue with skin and muscle tissue from her thigh. Surgeons then performed a Tracheotomy on Cameron, where they sliced a hole between her two collar bones and inserted a tube into her neck so she could breathe. The mum also had a feeding tube taped to her nose so she could ingest vital calories which were desperately needed to help her body recover. Read More Cameron said: They usually take skin from your forearm, but I’m only five foot two, so I didn’t have enough skin on my forearm to replace what I was having removed. However, Iaposve been an athlete all my le, and there was plenty for them to use from my thigh - so thataposs what we decided to do. The oral surgeon removed part of my tongue, and the plastic surgeon took muscle and skin from my thigh to replace it. When I woke up I had tubes coming out my neck and nose which allowed me to breathe and eat. The next few weeks were hell because my mouth was so swollen I couldnapost swallow or breathe unassisted. I had to be under constant observation and every time my throat had a build up of blood and body fluid, it had to be flushed away using water. That was basically like being waterboarded by the nurses once or twice a day which was absolutely horric. The weirdest part of the whole experience was when I felt a rough texture on the thigh part of my tongue - and when I looked in the mirror it had started growing leg hair! For nine weeks after her surgery, Cameron underwent  rounds of radiation and another three rounds of chemo to rid of any remaining cancer cells. In that time she was unable to speak, and for six months had to use a tube inserted in her stomach to eat and drink whilst her wounds healed. From then on, Cameron started getting used to le with her new tongue - which included relearning how to speak, chew, drink and swallow. I had to teach myself how to speak again after the radiation therapy which was a really bizarre feeling, she said. I can only taste on the right side of my tongue which is the real side, and only chew on the right side because the left is attached to my gums. My manners are terrible because food sometimes just falls out my mouth, and when food gets stuck underneath my tongue it feels like having a small rock in your shoe. Because the left side is sewn to my gums I donapost have the full range of motion I used to which can be frustrating. A feeling I could compare it to is like having a dead arm or dead leg all the time - it is constantly tingly and numb. Only the healthy side produces saliva and I cant stick my tongue out my mouth at all, so licking things is a big no no! Itaposs now been nine years since my diagnosis and thereaposs been no signs of regression. The longer you go without regressing the less likely it is the cancer will come back, so were all feeling really positive.  was the toughest year of my le and I couldnapost of done it without the support of my amazing Antony and the rest of my family. In June , once she proved she could eat and drink unaided, Cameron ed to her job as a gymnastics coach and was finally able to start living le again. She has since mentored several other people whoaposve been diagnosed with the same cancer as she was, offering them support and guidance throughout their treatment. story: Loch Ness Monster sighting in London a dead ringer for mythical beastA photograph taken beside Wimbledon Park Lake has captured a black outline in the water which could be a "dead ringer" for the famous "surgeons photograph" from A photograph taken at Wimbledon Lake is a dead ringer for the Surgeons Photograph - a picture said to show the Loch Ness Monsters neck and head Image: Arek ChytrosByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments This eerie photo of a strange object in a London lake is a dead ringer for the most famous Loch Ness Monster photograph of all time. The photo, which has been dubbed “Nessie in Wimbledon Park Lake”, captures a black outline in the water that looks exactly like the mythical beast. It’s particularly evocative of the famous “surgeon’s photograph” from  – supposedly the first image to capture the giant creatureaposs neck and head.Arek Chytros, who took the new “Nessie” photo, said he snapped it while strolling by the lake one morning. It picked up hundreds of likes and dozens of comments when he shared it online. “My goodness,” wrote one person. “Awesome,” said another.Do you believe in Nessie  Have your say in the comment section But it was not taken so seriously by others. One Londoner wrote: “That’s an escaped elephant. Anyone missing any ” Another said: “F***ing wild swimmers!” And one Scot commented: “On behalf of all Invernessians living in London, I can confirm that we endorse this message.” Others proposed that Arek had seen a cat, an exhaust system, a wheelbarrow or a Boris bike. While one person quipped that Nessie “took a holiday”.  The original “surgeon’s photograph” made headlines at the time, but is now believed to have been an elaborate hoax. It was apparently created using a toy submarine with wood putty attached, fashioned into a head and neck. For Arek, however, the hoax is not so elaborate. “It’s a tree,” he said. “As soon as I spotted it I thought of Nessie hence I snapped a picture.”  But Arek, a construction site manager, is keeping an open mind as to whether an actual Loch Ness Monster exists. “You never know what’s hiding in the unknown,” the -year-old said. “If a real Nessie exists then it’s gotta be some dinosaur that refused to go extinct. “I’d like to think that it does exist.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Loch Ness MonsterDinosaurs" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Astronomers spot spooky object never seen before sending mysterious signalsAstronomers from Curtin University, in Australia, have found a mysterious object in space that shines bright and then quickly disappears in a way that has not been seen beforeAstronomers have found a strange new object in space Image: PAByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A spooky object that keeps shining and then disappearing in space has been spotted by astronomers who say it is unlike anything seen before.The object appears to release a giant burst of energy three times an hour before disappearing, which has left astronomers scratching their heads. As it spins through space it sends out a beam of radiation, and for one minute in every twenty minutes it is one of the brightest objects in the sky. Researchers think the object could be a neutron star or a white dwarf - collapsed cores of stars - with an ultra-powerful magnetic field.Astrophysicist Dr Natasha Hurley-Walker, of Curtin University, International Centre for Radio Astronomy Researchin Australia, who led the team that made the discovery, called it spooky. She said: This object was appearing and disappearing over a few hours during our observations. That was completely unexpected. It was kind of spooky for an astronomer because thereaposs nothing known in the sky that does that. And itaposs really quite close to us - about , lightyears away. Itaposs in our galactic backyard. Dr Hurley-Walker added that the observations match a predicted astrophysical object called an ultra-long period magnetar. She said: Itaposs a type of slowly spinning neutron star that has been predicted to exist theoretically. But nobody expected to directly detect one like this, because we didnapost expect them to be so bright. Somehow itaposs converting magnetic energy to radio waves much more effectively than anything weaposve seen before. Curtin University Honours student Tyrone OaposDoherty discovered the object using the Murchison Widefield Arraytelescope in outback Western Australia - and a new technique he developed. He said: Itaposs exciting that the source I identied last year has turned out to be such a peculiar object. Objects that turn on and off in the universe are not new, and astronomers call them transients, with some appearing over the course of a few days and disappearing after a few months, and others flashing on and off within milliseconds or seconds. However, ICRAR-Curtin astrophysicist and co-author Dr Gemma Anderson said finding something that turned on for just a minute made the new discovery unusual. She explained that the mysterious object was incredibly bright and smaller than the sun, emitting the kind of radio waves that suggested it had an extremely strong magnetic field. The researchers are now monitoring the object to seeit switches back on, and plan to search for ore of these unusual objects in the vast archives of the MWA. More detections will tell astronomers whether this was a rare one-off event or a vast new population weaposd never noticed before, Dr Hurley-Walker said. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: bellanoch towpath to be closed until march
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowA section of the towpath on the Crinan Canal will be closed to the public until March.Scottish Canals took the decision to remove access to the section between Dunardy Lock  and Bellanoch Bridge after discovering an issue on the canal east of Bellanoch Bridge. title: biggar-man-called-sevens-team
story: A FORMER Biggar High School pupil has been selected to join the Scotland s squad.Reiss Cullen, , has travelled to Malaga to join Scotland’s s team on tour.On his selection, Reiss said: “It was a good feeling. It’s something I’ve wanted to do for my whole career and for it to finally become reality is exciting.”Reiss also plays for Watsonians in the Super, and previously played for Biggar.“He started in S at Biggar High School,” said his mum, Jo, “then he played with Biggar from S probably to about S and then he went to play for Watsonians.”She added: “He’s had so many knocks back, we’re absolutely chuffed for him.”Looking ahead to his time with the squad, Reiss said: “I’m looking forward to going away to dferent locations around the world with a tight group of boys and playing against the best players in the world.”Scotland have drawn in Pool A in the Malaga leg of the HSBC World Sevens Series. Reiss will play this weekend, before the team moves on to Seville.

title: victories-hawick-gala-biggar-melrose-weekend
story: IN A busy weekend of club rugby Hawick took the honours in the Premiership Borders derby, beating Jed-Forest - at the Riverside.Hawick’s tries came from Andrew Mitchell , Ruaridh McLeod and Shawn Muir. Kirk Ford scored four conversions and added two penalties. Gregor Young and Paulo Ferreira scored for Jed.That result all but secures Hawick’s place in the top-four play-offs. Jed are now in sixth place but still looking over their shoulders at the bottom of the table.Selkirk lost - in the capital to Edinburgh Accies. Their points came from two Scott Clark penalties and one from Callum Anderson. That result leaves the Souters in second bottom place which could see them needing a play off victory to retain their top-flight status.In National League One Gala secured a four-try bonus point - victory over Dundee in a hard fought encounter at Netherdale. Gala’s tries came from Taylor Wilson, Angus Dun, John Turnbull and Fergus Johnston. Craig Dods scored three conversions.Melrose ed to the Borders with five points after an emphatic - victory over Cartha Queen’s Park. Melrose tries came from Richard Ferguson, Gavin Wood , James Brown, Matthew Klein, Jack Dobie and Finn Douglas.Biggar beat Kelso - at Hartree Mill. Keith Melbourne scored Kelso’s try which Dwain Paterson converted. Paretson also added a penalty.These results leave Gala in third, five points behind Hariots Blues with two games in hand. Kelso are fourth and Melrose sixth.In National League Two Peebles lost - at home to GHK and in National League Three Berwick lost - away to Howe of Fe.In the Reserve League East One Hawick Force beat Boroughmuir -, Selkirk A lost - to Heriot’s Blues in Edinburgh and Jed-Forest A lost - away to Musselburgh.

title: galashiels-great-tapestry-centre-gets-5-star-visitscotland-rating
story: GALASHIELS’ Great Tapestry centre has been awarded a five-star rating following an inspection from Scotland’s national tourism organisation.The visitor attraction opened its doors to the Borders public back in August.And the centre has now been awarded the highest rating possible from VisitScotland after its first-ever ‘quality assurance’ inspection.Paula Ward, VisitScotland’s regional leadership director, officially presented the five-star visitor attraction status.:Police in Borders warn businesses following recent card machine scamsShe said: “To receive this five-star quality assurance award just a few months after opening is testament to the exceptional visitor experience on offer.“Quality assurance is more than just stars on the door, it is about the entire visitor experience. Our stars represent world class excellence, helping businesses shine, enabling visitors to make informed choices and driving investment in quality.Photo: Phil Wilkinson“The Great Tapestry of Scotland is already one of Scotland’s must-see national visitor attractions and a fantastic example of how tourism really is a force for good, creating wealth and social benefits for businesses and people in the south of Scotland, and enhancing the wellbeing of everyone who visits.”Naomi Harrod, owner of Unwind Yarns in Galashiels, said her store has seen an increase in footfall since the doors of the tapestry centre opened.The brainchild of Alexander McCall Smith, the Great Tapestry of Scotland was hand-stitched by a team of , stitchers from across Scotland, using  linen  and over  miles of wool.:Two arrested in connection with bogus caller incident at home of -year-old manIn addition to the tapestry itself, the centre houses visiting exhibits, a café and workshops.Director Sandy Maxwell-Forbes, who led the development of the new centre, said: “I am absolutely delighted we were awarded five stars from VisitScotland who have helped to create our wonderful new visitor centre..remove“I am incredibly proud of all that we have achieved and continue to achieve, particularly amidst a global pandemic.”Photo: Phil WilkinsonConservative Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine – the council’s executive member for wellbeing, sport and culture – added: “Accolades like this five-star rating do wonders to help promote the national signicance of this visitor attraction across the country and places Galashiels firmly on the map.“This national recognition can act as a springboard for further tourism to the local area and the wider region through  and beyond, providing wide-ranging benefits to businesses and communities alike.”The Great Tapestry of Scotland is operated by Live Borders, which manages many of the cultural and leisure facilities in the region.

title: round-shopping-nearest-pound-tesco-charities
story: SHOPPERS in Galashiels are being encouraged to help support an in-store fundraising campaign for three of the UK’s leading health charities.Last year Tescos ‘Helping you to live healthier’ campaign raised more than £ million after customers rounded up their shop to the nearest £ at self-service tills.Money raised will help Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK to continue their vital work to improve and save lives.As the charities fight back from the impact of the COVID- pandemic, Galashiels shoppers are once again being urged to round up their shopping to the nearest £ at self-service tills between  January and  February.Oonagh Turnbull, Head of Health Campaigns at Tesco, thanked Tesco shoppers in Galashiels for their generosity, which will make a signicant dference to many people’s lives.“The funds raised will continue to support the health of UK communities at such a critical time. Our health charity partners rely on donations to continue their awareness, prevention and research work.”The campaign is part of the Health Charity Partnership between Tesco, Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK. It is an ongoing initiative aimed at inspiring and supporting Tesco colleagues, customers and their families to make healthier food choices and live healthier lives.On behalf of the Health Charity Partnership, Caro Evans, Director of Partnerships at Cancer Research UK, said: “We’re delighted once again to be teaming up with Tesco to raise funds for research and for the vital support our charities provide."Cancer, heart and circulatory diseases, or diabetes affect nearly all of us so by working alongside Tesco we aim to empower millions of people to make healthier choices that can help lower their risk of these conditions."As always, we want to say a huge thank you to Tesco colleagues and customers in Galashiels for their support. With your help we can continue our work and continue to tackle some of the UK’s biggest health challenges.”

title: scotlands-world-cup-hopes-given-unexpected-boost
story: SCOTLANDS hopes of joining Australia, Wales and hosts New Zealand in Group A of the Women’s Rugby World Cup have been given an unexpected boost following the withdrawal of Samoa and Hong Kong from the tournament.A combination of lockdown restrictions in Hong Kong and challenges regarding re-entry into Samoa which includes a six-monthmoratorium for anyone who tests positive outside of the country meant that both teams are presently unable to travel to Dubai.Bryan Easson’s Scotland side reached the Final Qualication Tournament by finishing second in the European qualying tournament, beating Ireland in a nail-biting last game thanks to late try from Borderer Chloe Rollie.As the top ranked team, Scotland will now only need to play in the final match of the tournament on Friday  February .They will face the winner of Kazakhstan v Colombia, with the semi-final taking place on Saturday  February .The games will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.The Scots have not qualied for the World Cup since .World Rugby Chairman, Sir Bill Beaumont, said: “Our thoughts go out to the players and management who have worked tirelessly in preparation for this tournament and we would like to reassure them that every avenue was explored in attempt to find a solution to this unique and challenging situation.“The health and wellbeing of players, staff and spectators continues to be our number one priority as we continue to navigate the dynamic and complex nature of the ongoing COVID- pandemic. In collaboration with both Samoa and Hong Kong rugby unions, taking the appropriate measures that mitigate the spread of COVID- in line with the relevant authorities is paramount and has underpinned our decision making throughout the duration of the pandemic thus far.“We remain committed to delivering a safe Final Qualication Tournament for the remaining participating unions and will be working closely with Hong Kong and Samoa to ensure the best-possible  campaign for their women’s s teams.”.removeThe finals are scheduled to take place from  October until  November .

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-tariff-rates-proposed
story: TARIFF rates for charging electric vehicles in the region have been put forward by Scottish Borders Council .Elected members of the local authority are expected to back the proposals at a meeting on Thursday .Electric vehicle drivers had been able to charge for free due to Transport Scotland funding aimed at encouraging uptake of environmentally-friendly cars.According to SBC papers, rates at p per kWh for ‘journey ’ charge points and p per kWh for ‘all other ’ charge points are being proposed.:Borders woman who admitted drink-driving offence banned from road for  monthsThe report states: “There is currently no dedicated SBC revenue or capital budget allocated to EV infrastructure and any repairs that need to be carried out require to be assessed and funded along with other competing priorities from the ‘street lighting’ budget. Over the last two years £,. has been spent repairing chargers that were faulty. This is projected to increase as chargers progress further into their service le.”The report continues: “The proposal dferentiates between ‘journey’ and ‘destination’ chargers due to journey chargers being signicantly more expensive to purchase and maintain while also aligning closely with neighbouring authorities to provide a level of continuity.“The proposed pricing structure will encourage people who have the ability to charge at home to do so while also helping to ease pressure on the public charging network.“It will also help to create an environment that encourages commercial operators to invest in the installation of charging infrastructure within the Scottish Borders.:‘Must-see’ Great Tapestry centre receives -star rating from VisitScotland“Based on usage figures for  this gives a potential income in the region of £, a year, creating a surplus of around £, a year to contribute towards maintaining the current infrastructure..remove“This excludes overstay charges which would also generate additional surplus and would also allow scope to absorb any small increases in energy prices without the need to constantly alter the tarf.”Journey chargers can supply up to kW alternating current and up to kW direct current, can provide a full charge in around  minutes and are typically used to aid onward travel.Meanwhile, destination chargers y in charging time depending on the size of the charger, .kW units are used for overnight charging and .kW units typically take six to eight hours to fully charge a vehicle.If approved, SBC’s regime will see the introduction of an overstay charge, a minimum charge of £ per session and a p connection surcharge between pm-pm to ease demand on the electricity grid at peak times.:Coronavirus: Borders recorded  cases in last day, figures showSBC’s plans fall in line with schemes currently in place in East Lothian and Midlothian.In Dumfries  Galloway it costs p per kWh for all chargers, with a £. minimum charge.SBC currently has  chargers across  dferent towns and villages, of which the majority are rapid.Gordon Edgar – executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport – told a November meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was £,.A feasibility study has been commissioned to undertake a “region-wide, cross-sector assessment of supply, demand and commercial opportunities to create a strategic delivery model for EV charging infrastructure”.The work is expected to finish in .

in cases for this age group but the advice will be kept under "close and regular review".Strategic framework The First Minister was expected to outline a strategic framework or  roadmap to move the country to a “less restrictive” society.Ms Strugeon has confirmed that a full outline will be available in the coming weeks. Distance Aware SchemeNicola Sturgeon has encouraged Scots to take note of the Scottish Government’s Distance Aware scheme.The First Minister said badges and lanyards with the Distance Aware logo, indicating the wearer would like extra space, would be available to anyone who wants one.She said: “Soyou or anyone you know is worried about being out and about and would feel safer with a bit more space, please get a Distance Aware badge.“And for everyone ,you see someone wearing the badge or lanyard, give them the space and consideration that they are asking for.”Latest casesNicola Sturgeon also updated the Scottish parliament over the latest Covid cases. While the First Minister said that cases remain high, we are starting to see a "broadly positive picture"., new cases of COVID- reportedhave been reported as well as  new reported deaths of people who have tested positiveThere were  people in intensive care on Monday, January  with recently confirmed COVID- and , people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID-.Ms Sturgeon also noted that cases among under  years old are on the rise which is why the mask wearing in schools restriction has not been removed.The First Minister admitted that this has been the "toughest winter that the NHS has ever faced" and we should remain cautious.

title: borderers-celebrate-burns-wreath-laying-ceremony
story: MEMBERS of the Gala Burns Club celebrated Robert Burns at the weekend with a wreath laying ceremony in the town.Gathering at Lawyer’s Brae on Saturday , a group of club members came together to celebrate the Bard after their Burns’ Supper on Friday was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.“COVID had taken the decision [to cancel] for us,” said Gala Burns Club president Bruce Robertson.And at the wreath laying ceremony members were treated to a poetry recitation by -year-old Nicole Dalgleish and piping from Angus Campbell who won the Robert Burns World Federation Cup in bagpiping in .Looking to the future, Mr Robertson says the club has plans to hold a social event for members later in the year.He said: “We’re hoping to organise a social event in early April or May.“Not a supper but a gathering.“But it depends on the COVID situation.“It’s on the books for the near future to get members back for a social evening to help keep Burns alive in Galashiels.”

title: hammer-recommends-lowland-league-young-players
story: FORMER Gala Fairydean Rovers player Jamie Gullan is looking forward to lining up in front of , fans at Celtic Park next month in the fth round of the Scottish Cup.And the -year-old believes that his loan spell at Netherdale has contributed to his progress in the game.Nicknamed ‘The Hammer’ by fans and team mates the player joined Hibernian in  after starting in the Hearts youth system.He quickly progressed through the Academy ranks scoring one of the goals in the final as Hibs beat Aberdeen to win the – Scottish Youth Cup.In  he joined Gala Fairydean Rovers after impressing in a - victory for the Edinburgh side in a friendly at Netherdale.And he enjoyed a successful spell in the Borders under Steve Noble, scoring three-goals for the club.Gullan is now encouraging other young players to follow in his footsteps, although not in his boots!Jamie told the Border : “Joining Gala was a good learning curve and dferent to being about the Hibs training centre but I enjoyed it. It was a really good first taste of men’s football which was physical and tough, and I improved because of that."I played up front with Stuart Noble and learned a lot from him and others in the team, including not to wear pink boots. We had a good dressing room and I still keep in touch with some of the players and keep an eye on the scores.“I’d play for Gala on the Saturday and then play for the Hibs reserves in midweek, so I got plenty of game time. Gala are a fantastic club and everyone made me feel very welcome from the beginning."I would definitely recommend going on loan to the Lowland League to all youngsters trying to make the grade. Because Rangers and Celtic are in it now, the league has a much higher profile.”After ing to Hibs, Neil Lennon gave him his first-team debut against Faroese club NSI Runavik in the Europa League qualiers in July  and since then he featured in  games, scoring three goals, all of them in cup competitions..removeHis first was in a - victory over Inverness Caledonian Thistle in the quarter-final of the Scottish Cup but just as he was starting to become a regular in the first-team, COVID struck and football was suspended before ing without fans.Earlier this month he joined Championship side Raith Rovers for an undisclosed fee having played with the Fe side on-loan on three occasions.

title: greens-announce-candidate-gala-ahead-council-election
story: THE Scottish Borders Green Party has announced its candidate for the Galashiels and District ward at this year’s council elections.Fty-five-year-old Neil MacKinnon will contest the ward at the elections set to be held in May.This will be the first time the father of three has stood in an election, however, he has worked with previous Scottish Green Party campaigns.Mr MacKinnon says he is ‘honoured’ to have been selected to represent the Scottish Borders Greens.He said: “I am honoured to have been chosen for this role and hope to be elected so I can serve the people of Galashiels.“With the climate emergency a real and present danger it is important to elect Green politicians to every level of government to help drive the change that is required to meet this emergency head on.“No action by any council or inidual is too small not to count.”Mr MacKinnon, who is originally from Peebles but has lived in Galashiels for most of his le, says one of his goals is to encourage the use of ‘micro-generation projects’ in the town, as well as across the region. Another is to see a greater roll-out of electric vehicles.He said: “The council should be encouraging micro-generation projects, solar and small-scale wind on public buildings like village halls and libraries.“The privately funded river turbine at Philiphaugh should be a model for the council to promote the use of the fast flowing rivers in most Borders towns as a reliable and sustainable source of power.”The scientic equipment engineer added: “Many people in the region, especially in Galashiels, live in accommodation where charging an electric vehicle is just not possible. There needs to be a drive for on-street charging points in residential areas through the Borders.”Mr MacKinnon is joined by Dominic Ashmole who will stand for the Scottish Borders Greens in the Tweeddale West ward in the May elections.
